sen.j: 方相氏（ほうそうし）と呼ばれる鬼を払う役目を負った役人（大舎人（おおとねり））と、方相氏の脇に仕える侲子（しんし）と呼ばれる役人（特に役職は決まっていない）が二十人で、大内裏の中を掛け声をかけつつ回った。
sen.e: In those days, a total of 20 government officials, including those called Hososhi, who were responsible for expelling ogres (Otoneri, or Royal Attendant) and others called Shinshi, who support Hososhi, participated in the event, and they called out while walking around within the Dai-dairi (the place of the Imperial Palace and government offices).

sen.j: 方相氏が大内裏を回るとき、公卿は清涼殿の階(きざはし)から弓矢をもって方相氏に対して弓 (武器)をひき、殿上人（でんじょうびと）らは振り鼓(でんでん太鼓)をふって厄を払った。
sen.e: When Hososhi went around the Dai-dairi, court nobles, having Yumiya/Kyushi (a bow and an arrow) in their hands, drew a bow (a weapon) at Hososhi from the stairs in the Seiryoden (Literally "Limpid Cool Hall," an imperial summer palace), and tenjobito (high-ranking courtiers allowed into the Imperial Palace) performed exorcism by twisting the handle of furitsuzumi (a Den-Den Daiko; a twist drum: Small toy whirling drum on handle. Two beads on strings attached to shell strike drum when the handle is twisted).

sen.e: However, Hososhi, who had been responsible for expelling ogres, began to be expelled as ogres in turn in the middle of the ninth century.

sen.j: 古代史家の三宅和朗はこの変化について、平安初期における触穢信仰の高まりが、葬送儀礼にも深く関わっていた方相氏に対する忌避感を強め、穢れとして追われる側に変化させたのではないかとしている。
sen.e: Kazuo MIYAKE, an ancient historian explains that this change may have occurred because popularity of Shokue shinko (uncleanliness religion) in the early Heian period developed the sense of avoidance against Hososhi, who had been deeply related with funeral rites, and altered the position of Hososhi to be expelled as impurities.

sen.e: At the Jimoku executed during the ceremony of Tsuina, appointment was made for those who received no appointment at the Agatameshi no jimoku (ceremony for appointing local officials) in spring or at the Tsukasameshi no jimoku (ceremony for appointing Kyoto officials) in autumn.
